title: My Lab Journal
text: This is a template example for lab journaling. Students in the data science courses at the Institute of Entrepreneurship will use this template to learn R for business analytics. Students can replace this text as they wish.

title: My Lab Journal
text:
How to use

Accept the assignment and get your own github repo.
Blog/journal what you are doing in R, by editing the .qmd files.
See the links page for lots of helpful links on learning R.
Change everything to make it your own.
Make sure to render you website every time before you want to upload changes.

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
library(dplyr)

random_vars <- readRDS("~/Documents/TUHH/Casual Data Science for Business Analytics/Causal_Data_Science_Data/random_vars.rds")




ageExpectedValue <- summarise(random_vars, mean = mean(age))
print(ageExpectedValue)

#> # A tibble: 1 × 1
#>    mean
#>   <dbl>
#> 1  33.5

ageVariance <- var(random_vars[,1])
print(ageVariance)

#>          age
#> age 340.6078

ageStandardDeviation <- summarise(random_vars, sd = sd(age))
print(ageStandardDeviation)

#> # A tibble: 1 × 1
#>      sd
#>   <dbl>
#> 1  18.5






incomeExpectedValue <- summarise(random_vars, mean = mean(income))
print(incomeExpectedValue)

#> # A tibble: 1 × 1
#>    mean
#>   <dbl>
#> 1 3511.

random_vars %>%
  select(-income) %>%
  var()

#>          age
#> age 340.6078

incomeStandardDeviation <- summarise(random_vars, sd = sd(income))
print(incomeStandardDeviation)

#> # A tibble: 1 × 1
#>      sd
#>   <dbl>
#> 1 2937.






Well I believe that there’s no sense to compare the standard deviations because simple the income and age aren’t directly related and hence we cannot say that if someone’s age is above the mean with a certain deviation that their income will increase by a certain deviation and vice versa




cov <- cov(random_vars[,1],random_vars[,2])
print(cov)

#>       income
#> age 29700.15

cor <- cor(random_vars[,1],random_vars[,2])
print(cor)

#>        income
#> age 0.5479432





Correlation is easier to interpret because it is bounded with the magnitude showing us how strong or how weak is the relationship and the sign shows us the direction. Meanwhile the covariance is value that doesn’t really tell us much, in terms of the number provided.




\(E[income \mid age >= 18]\)


e1 <- summarise(random_vars[random_vars$age>=18,], mean = mean(income))
print(e1)

#> # A tibble: 1 × 1
#>    mean
#>   <dbl>
#> 1 4464.



\(E[income \mid age \in [18,65)]\)


e2 <- summarise(random_vars[random_vars$age >= 18 & random_vars$age<65,], mean = mean(income))
print(e2)

#> # A tibble: 1 × 1
#>    mean
#>   <dbl>
#> 1 4686.



\(E[income \mid age >= 65]\)


e3 <- summarise(random_vars[random_vars$age >= 65,], mean = mean(income))
print(e3)

#> # A tibble: 1 × 1
#>    mean
#>   <dbl>
#> 1 1777.

title: Probability Theory
text:
\(P(T \cap S) = P(T \mid S) * P(S) = 0.2 *0.3 = 0.06\)
\(P(T \cap \overline{S}) = P(T \mid \overline{S}) * P(\overline{S}) = 0.6 *0.7 = 0.42\)
\(P(\overline{T} \cap S) = P(\overline{T} \mid S) * P(S) = 0.8 *0.3 = 0.24\)
\(P(\overline{T} \cap \overline{S}) = P(\overline{T} \mid \overline{S}) * P(\overline{S}) = 0.7 *0.4 = 0.28\)

title: Regression and Statistical Inference
text:
library(tidyverse)

#> ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
#> ✔ dplyr     1.1.3     ✔ readr     2.1.4
#> ✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.0
#> ✔ ggplot2   3.4.4     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
#> ✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.0
#> ✔ purrr     1.0.2     
#> ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
#> ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
#> ✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
#> ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

car_prices <- readRDS("~/Documents/TUHH/Casual Data Science for Business Analytics/Causal_Data_Science_Data/car_prices.rds")

dim(car_prices)

#> [1] 181  22


The dimensions of the data set is 188 rows and 22 coloumns




glimpse(car_prices)

#> Rows: 181
#> Columns: 22
#> $ aspiration       <chr> "std", "std", "std", "std", "std", "std", "std", "std…
#> $ doornumber       <chr> "two", "two", "two", "four", "four", "two", "four", "…
#> $ carbody          <chr> "convertible", "convertible", "hatchback", "sedan", "…
#> $ drivewheel       <chr> "rwd", "rwd", "rwd", "fwd", "4wd", "fwd", "fwd", "fwd…
#> $ enginelocation   <chr> "front", "front", "front", "front", "front", "front",…
#> $ wheelbase        <dbl> 88.6, 88.6, 94.5, 99.8, 99.4, 99.8, 105.8, 105.8, 105…
#> $ carlength        <dbl> 168.8, 168.8, 171.2, 176.6, 176.6, 177.3, 192.7, 192.…
#> $ carwidth         <dbl> 64.1, 64.1, 65.5, 66.2, 66.4, 66.3, 71.4, 71.4, 71.4,…
#> $ carheight        <dbl> 48.8, 48.8, 52.4, 54.3, 54.3, 53.1, 55.7, 55.7, 55.9,…
#> $ curbweight       <dbl> 2548, 2548, 2823, 2337, 2824, 2507, 2844, 2954, 3086,…
#> $ enginetype       <chr> "dohc", "dohc", "ohcv", "ohc", "ohc", "ohc", "ohc", "…
#> $ cylindernumber   <chr> "four", "four", "six", "four", "five", "five", "five"…
#> $ enginesize       <dbl> 130, 130, 152, 109, 136, 136, 136, 136, 131, 131, 108…
#> $ fuelsystem       <chr> "mpfi", "mpfi", "mpfi", "mpfi", "mpfi", "mpfi", "mpfi…
#> $ boreratio        <dbl> 3.47, 3.47, 2.68, 3.19, 3.19, 3.19, 3.19, 3.19, 3.13,…
#> $ stroke           <dbl> 2.68, 2.68, 3.47, 3.40, 3.40, 3.40, 3.40, 3.40, 3.40,…
#> $ compressionratio <dbl> 9.00, 9.00, 9.00, 10.00, 8.00, 8.50, 8.50, 8.50, 8.30…
#> $ horsepower       <dbl> 111, 111, 154, 102, 115, 110, 110, 110, 140, 160, 101…
#> $ peakrpm          <dbl> 5000, 5000, 5000, 5500, 5500, 5500, 5500, 5500, 5500,…
#> $ citympg          <dbl> 21, 21, 19, 24, 18, 19, 19, 19, 17, 16, 23, 23, 21, 2…
#> $ highwaympg       <dbl> 27, 27, 26, 30, 22, 25, 25, 25, 20, 22, 29, 29, 28, 2…
#> $ price            <dbl> 13495.00, 16500.00, 16500.00, 13950.00, 17450.00, 152…


Here I used glimpse instead of head to help me see all the coloums and their data types. Strings are recorded as chars and numbers are double allowing decimal values.




lm_all <- lm(price ~ ., data = car_prices)
summary(lm_all)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = price ~ ., data = car_prices)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>    Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max 
#>  -5662  -1120      0    798   9040 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                        Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)          -36269.965  15460.866  -2.346 0.020354 *  
#> aspirationturbo        1846.206   1041.391   1.773 0.078386 .  
#> doornumbertwo           242.523    571.929   0.424 0.672172    
#> carbodyhardtop        -3691.743   1424.825  -2.591 0.010561 *  
#> carbodyhatchback      -3344.335   1238.359  -2.701 0.007757 ** 
#> carbodysedan          -2292.820   1356.014  -1.691 0.093043 .  
#> carbodywagon          -3427.921   1490.285  -2.300 0.022885 *  
#> drivewheelfwd          -504.564   1076.623  -0.469 0.640030    
#> drivewheelrwd           -15.446   1268.070  -0.012 0.990299    
#> enginelocationrear     6643.492   2572.275   2.583 0.010806 *  
#> wheelbase               -30.197     92.776  -0.325 0.745294    
#> carlength               -29.740     51.672  -0.576 0.565824    
#> carwidth                731.819    244.533   2.993 0.003258 ** 
#> carheight               123.195    134.607   0.915 0.361617    
#> curbweight                2.612      1.781   1.467 0.144706

#> enginetypel             978.748   1786.384   0.548 0.584619    
#> enginetypeohc          3345.252    933.001   3.585 0.000461 ***
#> enginetypeohcf          972.919   1625.631   0.598 0.550462    
#> enginetypeohcv        -6222.322   1236.415  -5.033 1.43e-06 ***
#> cylindernumberfive   -11724.540   3019.192  -3.883 0.000157 ***
#> cylindernumberfour   -11549.326   3177.177  -3.635 0.000387 ***
#> cylindernumbersix     -7151.398   2247.230  -3.182 0.001793 ** 
#> cylindernumberthree   -4318.929   4688.833  -0.921 0.358545    
#> cylindernumbertwelve -11122.209   4196.494  -2.650 0.008946 ** 
#> enginesize              125.934     26.541   4.745 5.00e-06 ***
#> fuelsystem2bbl          177.136    883.615   0.200 0.841400    
#> fuelsystemmfi         -3041.018   2576.996  -1.180 0.239934    
#> fuelsystemmpfi          359.278   1001.529   0.359 0.720326    
#> fuelsystemspdi        -2543.890   1363.546  -1.866 0.064140 .  
#> fuelsystemspfi          514.766   2499.229   0.206 0.837107    
#> boreratio             -1306.740   1642.221  -0.796 0.427516    
#> stroke                -4527.137    922.732  -4.906 2.49e-06 ***
#> compressionratio       -737.901    555.960  -1.327 0.186539    
#> horsepower               10.293     22.709   0.453 0.651035    
#> peakrpm                   2.526      0.634   3.983 0.000108 ***
#> citympg                 -90.352    166.647  -0.542 0.588538    
#> highwaympg              154.858    167.148   0.926 0.355761    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 2189 on 143 degrees of freedom

#> F-statistic: 62.21 on 37 and 143 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16


From the summary we could see that the main factors relevant are:

enginetype (mostly)
eniginesize
stroke
peakrpm





lm_top <- lm(price ~ enginetype +
                     enginesize +
                     stroke +
                     peakrpm,
                     data = car_prices)
summary(lm_top)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = price ~ enginetype + enginesize + stroke + peakrpm, 
#>     data = car_prices)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
#> -14872.1  -1453.3   -410.3   1563.4  10058.4 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                   Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)     -1.618e+04  4.220e+03  -3.834 0.000177 ***
#> enginetypedohcv  1.280e+03  3.135e+03   0.408 0.683638    
#> enginetypel      3.842e+03  1.480e+03   2.596 0.010256 *  
#> enginetypeohc    2.550e+03  9.641e+02   2.645 0.008925 ** 
#> enginetypeohcf   6.534e+02  1.283e+03   0.509 0.611213    
#> enginetypeohcv  -4.967e+03  1.284e+03  -3.870 0.000154 ***
#> enginesize       2.145e+02  7.630e+00  28.106  < 2e-16 ***
#> stroke          -5.398e+03  9.088e+02  -5.939 1.55e-08 ***
#> peakrpm          3.400e+00  5.522e-01   6.158 5.05e-09 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 2971 on 172 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.8704, Adjusted R-squared:  0.8644 
#> F-statistic: 144.4 on 8 and 172 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16


As we can see the smallest p-value is the one for engine size and hence im picking it to be my regressor.

max(car_prices$enginesize)

#> [1] 326

min(car_prices$enginesize)

#> [1] 61


The regressor I chose is of type double and its values in this data set ranges from 61 to 326.
It has a big effect on the price since the p value is very small it denies the null hypothesis and tells that that there is a strong corellation between both factors.

lm_summarised <- lm(price ~ enginesize, data = car_prices)
confint(lm_summarised, level = 0.95)

#>                   2.5 %     97.5 %
#> (Intercept) -10346.0474 -6898.5441
#> enginesize     157.1932   182.9353


The estimate is completely positive hence the effect is statistically significant.




new_car_prices <- mutate(car_prices, seat_heating = TRUE)
lm_heat <- lm(price ~ ., data = new_car_prices)
summary(lm_heat)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = price ~ ., data = new_car_prices)

title: Regression Discontinuity
text:
Note



You can delete everything in here and start fresh.

title: Probability Theory
text:
Givens
\(P(B \mid A) = 0.97\)
\(P(B \mid \overline{A}) = 0.01\)
\(P(A) = 0.04\)

title: Probability Theory
text:
\(P(T \cap S) = P(T \mid S) * P(S) = 0.2 *0.3 = 0.06\)
\(P(T \cap \overline{S}) = P(T \mid \overline{S}) * P(\overline{S}) = 0.6 *0.7 = 0.42\)
\(P(\overline{T} \cap S) = P(\overline{T} \mid S) * P(S) = 0.8 *0.3 = 0.24\)
\(P(\overline{T} \cap \overline{S}) = P(\overline{T} \mid \overline{S}) * P(\overline{S}) = 0.7 *0.4 = 0.28\)

title: Probability Theory
text:
## Solution

\(P(T \cap S) = P(T \mid S) * P(S) = 0.2 *0.3 = 0.06\)
\(P(T \cap \overline{S}) = P(T \mid \overline{S}) * P(\overline{S}) = 0.6 *0.7 = 0.42\)
\(P(\overline{T} \cap S) = P(\overline{T} \mid S) * P(S) = 0.8 *0.3 = 0.24\)
\(P(\overline{T} \cap \overline{S}) = P(\overline{T} \mid \overline{S}) * P(\overline{S}) = 0.7 *0.4 = 0.28\)

title: Probability Theory
text: Given

title: Probability Theory
text:
Solution

Percentage of customers using all 3 devices:
\((Smartphone \cap Tablet \cap Computer) = 0.5\%\)
Percentage of customers using at least 2 devices:
\((Smartphone \cap Tablet \cap Computer) + (Smartphone \cap Tablet) +(Tablet \cap Computer) + (Smartphone \cap Computer)\)
\(= 0.5\% + 7.3\% + 3.3\% + 8.8\% = 19.9\%\)
Percentage of customers using only 1 device = Percentage of users - Percentage of users using at least 2 devices:
\(100\% - 19.9\% = 80.1\%\)

title: Probability Theory
text:
Solution

\(P(\overline{A} \mid B) = \frac{P(B \mid \overline{A}) * P(\overline{A})}{P(B)} = \frac{P(B \mid \overline{A}) * P(\overline{A})}{P(B \mid \overline{A})*P(\overline{A}) + P(B \mid A) * P(A)} = \frac{0.01*0.96}{(0.01*0.96)+(0.97*0.04)} = 0.198\)
\(P(A \mid B) = 1 - P(\overline{A} \mid B) = 1 - 0.192 = 0.802\)
OR
\(P(A \mid B) = \frac{P(B \mid A) * P(A)}{P(B)} = \frac{P(B \mid A) * P(A)}{P(B \mid A) * P(A) + P(B \mid \overline{A})*P(\overline{A})} = \frac{0.97*0.04}{(0.97*0.04)+(0.01*0.96)} = 0.802\)

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
library(dplyr)

random_vars <- readRDS("~/Documents/TUHH/Casual Data Science for Business Analytics/Causal_Data_Science_Data/random_vars.rds")




ageExpectedValue <- summarise(random_vars, mean = mean(age))
print(ageExpectedValue)

#> # A tibble: 1 × 1
#>    mean
#>   <dbl>
#> 1  33.5

ageVariance <- var(random_vars[,1])
print(ageVariance)

#>          age
#> age 340.6078

ageStandardDeviation <- summarise(random_vars, sd = sd(age))
print(ageStandardDeviation)

#> # A tibble: 1 × 1
#>      sd
#>   <dbl>
#> 1  18.5






incomeExpectedValue <- summarise(random_vars, mean = mean(income))
print(incomeExpectedValue)

#> # A tibble: 1 × 1
#>    mean
#>   <dbl>
#> 1 3511.

random_vars %>%
  select(-income) %>%
  var()

#>          age
#> age 340.6078

incomeStandardDeviation <- summarise(random_vars, sd = sd(income))
print(incomeStandardDeviation)

#> # A tibble: 1 × 1
#>      sd
#>   <dbl>
#> 1 2937.

title: Statistical Concepts
text: Well I believe that there’s no sense to compare the standard deviations because simple the income and age aren’t directly related and hence we cannot say that if someone’s age is above the mean with a certain deviation that their income will increase by a certain deviation and vice versa

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
cov <- cov(random_vars[,1],random_vars[,2])
print(cov)

#>       income
#> age 29700.15

cor <- cor(random_vars[,1],random_vars[,2])
print(cor)

#>        income
#> age 0.5479432

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
\(E[income \mid age >= 18]\)


e1 <- summarise(random_vars[random_vars$age>=18,], mean = mean(income))
print(e1)

#> # A tibble: 1 × 1
#>    mean
#>   <dbl>
#> 1 4464.



\(E[income \mid age \in [18,65)]\)


e2 <- summarise(random_vars[random_vars$age >= 18 & random_vars$age<65,], mean = mean(income))
print(e2)

#> # A tibble: 1 × 1
#>    mean
#>   <dbl>
#> 1 4686.



\(E[income \mid age >= 65]\)


e3 <- summarise(random_vars[random_vars$age >= 65,], mean = mean(income))
print(e3)

#> # A tibble: 1 × 1
#>    mean
#>   <dbl>
#> 1 1777.

title: Statistical Concepts
text: Correlation is easier to interpret because it is bounded with the magnitude showing us how strong or how weak is the relationship and the sign shows us the direction. Meanwhile the covariance is value that doesn’t really tell us much, in terms of the number provided.

title: Regression and Statistical Inference
text:
library(tidyverse)

#> ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
#> ✔ dplyr     1.1.3     ✔ readr     2.1.4
#> ✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.0
#> ✔ ggplot2   3.4.4     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
#> ✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.0

car_prices <- readRDS("~/Documents/TUHH/Casual Data Science for Business Analytics/Causal_Data_Science_Data/car_prices.rds")

dim(car_prices)

#> [1] 181  22


The dimensions of the data set is 188 rows and 22 coloumns

title: Regression and Statistical Inference
text:
glimpse(car_prices)

#> Rows: 181
#> Columns: 22
#> $ aspiration       <chr> "std", "std", "std", "std", "std", "std", "std", "std…
#> $ doornumber       <chr> "two", "two", "two", "four", "four", "two", "four", "…
#> $ carbody          <chr> "convertible", "convertible", "hatchback", "sedan", "…

#> $ enginetype       <chr> "dohc", "dohc", "ohcv", "ohc", "ohc", "ohc", "ohc", "…
#> $ cylindernumber   <chr> "four", "four", "six", "four", "five", "five", "five"…
#> $ enginesize       <dbl> 130, 130, 152, 109, 136, 136, 136, 136, 131, 131, 108…
#> $ fuelsystem       <chr> "mpfi", "mpfi", "mpfi", "mpfi", "mpfi", "mpfi", "mpfi…
#> $ boreratio        <dbl> 3.47, 3.47, 2.68, 3.19, 3.19, 3.19, 3.19, 3.19, 3.13,…
#> $ stroke           <dbl> 2.68, 2.68, 3.47, 3.40, 3.40, 3.40, 3.40, 3.40, 3.40,…
#> $ compressionratio <dbl> 9.00, 9.00, 9.00, 10.00, 8.00, 8.50, 8.50, 8.50, 8.30…
#> $ horsepower       <dbl> 111, 111, 154, 102, 115, 110, 110, 110, 140, 160, 101…
#> $ peakrpm          <dbl> 5000, 5000, 5000, 5500, 5500, 5500, 5500, 5500, 5500,…
#> $ citympg          <dbl> 21, 21, 19, 24, 18, 19, 19, 19, 17, 16, 23, 23, 21, 2…
#> $ highwaympg       <dbl> 27, 27, 26, 30, 22, 25, 25, 25, 20, 22, 29, 29, 28, 2…
#> $ price            <dbl> 13495.00, 16500.00, 16500.00, 13950.00, 17450.00, 152…


Here I used glimpse instead of head to help me see all the coloums and their data types. Strings are recorded as chars and numbers are double allowing decimal values.

title: Regression and Statistical Inference
text:
lm_top <- lm(price ~ enginetype +
                     enginesize +
                     stroke +
                     peakrpm,
                     data = car_prices)
summary(lm_top)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = price ~ enginetype + enginesize + stroke + peakrpm, 
#>     data = car_prices)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
#> -14872.1  -1453.3   -410.3   1563.4  10058.4 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                   Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)     -1.618e+04  4.220e+03  -3.834 0.000177 ***
#> enginetypedohcv  1.280e+03  3.135e+03   0.408 0.683638    
#> enginetypel      3.842e+03  1.480e+03   2.596 0.010256 *  
#> enginetypeohc    2.550e+03  9.641e+02   2.645 0.008925 ** 
#> enginetypeohcf   6.534e+02  1.283e+03   0.509 0.611213    
#> enginetypeohcv  -4.967e+03  1.284e+03  -3.870 0.000154 ***
#> enginesize       2.145e+02  7.630e+00  28.106  < 2e-16 ***
#> stroke          -5.398e+03  9.088e+02  -5.939 1.55e-08 ***
#> peakrpm          3.400e+00  5.522e-01   6.158 5.05e-09 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 2971 on 172 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.8704, Adjusted R-squared:  0.8644 
#> F-statistic: 144.4 on 8 and 172 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16


As we can see the smallest p-value is the one for engine size and hence im picking it to be my regressor.

max(car_prices$enginesize)

#> [1] 326

min(car_prices$enginesize)

#> [1] 61


The regressor I chose is of type double and its values in this data set ranges from 61 to 326.
It has a big effect on the price since the p value is very small it denies the null hypothesis and tells that that there is a strong corellation between both factors.

lm_summarised <- lm(price ~ enginesize, data = car_prices)
confint(lm_summarised, level = 0.95)

#>                   2.5 %     97.5 %
#> (Intercept) -10346.0474 -6898.5441
#> enginesize     157.1932   182.9353


The estimate is completely positive hence the effect is statistically significant.
